greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: T(n,k) = Stirling2(n,k) * OrderedBell(k)
comment: T(n,k) is the number of preferential arrangements of the k-part partitions of the set {1...n}.
2*T(n,k) is the number of formulas in first order logic that have an n-place predicate and use k variables, but don't include a negator.
4*T(n,k) is the number of such formulas that may include an negator.
The entries T(n,n) are A000670(n), i.e. the ordered Bell numbers.
link: Tilman Piesk, Preferential arrangements of set partitions (Wikiversity)
formula: Recurrence equation (for entries not on main diagonal): (n - k)*T(n,k) = C(n,1)*T(n-1,k) - C(n,2)*T(n-2,k) + C(n,3)*T(n-3,k) - ... (End)
example: Let the colon ":" be a separator between two levels. E.g. in {1,2}:{3} the set {1,2} is on the first level, the set {3} is on the second level.
Compare descriptions of A083355 and A233357.
xref: A008277 (Stirling2), A000670 (ordered Bell), A068156 (column k=2), A083355 (row sums: number of preferential arrangements), A233357 (number of preferential arrangements by number of levels).
results.author: _Tilman Piesk_, Nov 26 2013
